unnormalised: Diwali in our family is never just one day; it’s a week-long affair, really. It always starts a week or so before the actual day – tentatively around 25/10, depending on the year, of course. This year, 2024, Diwali falls on 31/10, and the prep work has already begun. Ma started cleaning on 23/10, a whole 8 days beforehand! She insists on a completely spotless house before Lakshmi Puja.
normalised: Diwali in our family is never just one day; it’s a week-long affair, really. It always starts a week or so before the actual day – tentatively around twenty fifth October, depending on the year, of course. This year, two thousand and twenty four, Diwali falls on thirty first October, and the prep work has already begun. Ma started cleaning on twenty third October, a whole eight days beforehand! She insists on a completely spotless house before Lakshmi Puja.

unnormalised: I remember one year, it must have been around 2010 or '11, when Diwali fell unusually late, maybe even the 5th or 6th of November. I was in college then, home for the break. The entire house smelled of freshly fried snacks starting from the 28th, a full 3 days before. The aroma of 'chaklis' and 'ladoos' filled every corner. Dad was in charge of getting the fireworks, always a huge task. He usually got them on the 30th Oct, at the very last minute, from the wholesale market in Burrabazar.
normalised: I remember one year, it must have been around two thousand and ten or eleven, when Diwali fell unusually late, maybe even the fifth or sixth of November. I was in college then, home for the break. The entire house smelled of freshly fried snacks starting from the twenty eighth, a full three days before. The aroma of 'chaklis' and 'ladoos' filled every corner. Dad was in charge of getting the fireworks, always a huge task. He usually got them on the thirtieth October, at the very last minute, from the wholesale market in Burrabazar.

unnormalised: The Lakshmi Puja itself is always at precisely 7:15 PM. Punditji is very particular about the 'shubh muhurat'. He’s been our family priest for generations. After the puja, it's all about the food, the lights, and the crackers. We’d light up the entire neighbourhood. It used to go on till almost 1:00 AM.
normalised: The Lakshmi Puja itself is always at precisely seven fifteen P-M. Punditji is very particular about the 'shubh muhurat'. He’s been our family priest for generations. After the puja, it's all about the food, the lights, and the crackers. We’d light up the entire neighbourhood. It used to go on till almost one A-M.

unnormalised: Then there’s Bhai Dooj, 02/11, two days after Diwali. My sister, Diya, ties 'rakhi' on my wrist (even though it's not really Raksha Bandhan) and we exchange gifts. Ma makes a special 'thali' of sweets and snacks. It's a sweet ending to a very sweet festival.
normalised: Then there’s Bhai Dooj, second November, two days after Diwali. My sister, Diya, ties 'rakhi' on my wrist (even though it's not really Raksha Bandhan) and we exchange gifts. Ma makes a special 'thali' of sweets and snacks. It's a sweet ending to a very sweet festival.

unnormalised: Now, with 31/10 approaching, the excitement is palpable. The Diwali cleaning is in full swing, the snack-making will start any minute, and Dad is already scouting for the best deals on fireworks. It's a time for family, for traditions, and for making memories that will last another year – until around 20th Oct next year, when the preparations start all over again!
